title: Feasibility/Desirability Games for Normal Form Games, Choice Models and Evolutionary Games
summary:
**Problem:**  
Because plain old normal form games are just too mainstream, this paper proposes Feasibility/Desirability (FD) Games to “unify” game theory, microeconomics, and evolutionary dynamics under one slightly confusing roof.

**Approach:**  
They whip up a fancy abstraction layering feasibility and desirability relations over normal form games, then claim it’s a fresh lens to find Nash equilibria, model economic choices, and track evolutionary strategies simultaneously. Multitasking much?

**Key Results:**  
They characterize equilibria by combining feasibility and desirability links—because apparently, you need more than just payoffs to make sense of games. Also, they shoehorn applications into economics and evolution, like a Swiss Army knife of game theory.

**Why It Matters:**  
If you enjoy mixing metaphors and mathematical frameworks, this unifying approach might make you feel smarter. Otherwise, it’s another theoretical playground with minimal impact on actual gaming or decision-making practice. But hey, at least it’s not “just another normal form game.”

title: Equivalence between quantum simultaneous games and quantum sequential games
summary:
**Problem:** The paper tackles the mind-boggling quest of proving that quantum simultaneous games and quantum sequential games—two supposedly different beasts—are actually just flip sides of the same quantum coin. Because apparently, we needed more quantum confusion in gaming theory.

**Approach:** The author painstakingly defines all the fancy quantum game types and then embarks on a 10-page proof journey, complete with figures, to show that for every quantum simultaneous game, there's an equivalent sequential one. Spoiler: the finite cases get the same treatment.

**Key Results:** Surprise! The paper confirms that quantum simultaneous and sequential games are equivalent, both in infinite and finite flavors. So, if you thought these were fundamentally different, prepare to update your quantum gaming bingo card.

**Why It Matters:** This “unification” might someday help quantum game theorists stop arguing about game types and focus on, I don’t know, actually building quantum games? Until then, it’s a neat theoretical footnote in an already niche field.

title: Some observations on the mildly Menger property and topological games
summary:
Alright, gamers and game-theorists, strap in. Here’s your weekly dose of “Why am I even reading this?” from the depths of gaming-related research—this time, topological games that sound like they belong in a philosophy class, not your Steam library.

---

**Title:** Some observations on the mildly Menger property and topological games

**Problem:**  
Because apparently classical topological games weren’t confusing enough, these geniuses want to define two new ones—mildly Menger and compact-clopen games—to probe the mysteries of zero-dimensional spaces. Yes, zero-dimensional. Groundbreaking.

**Approach:**  
They introduce a third game (K-quasi-component-clopen) to prove it’s basically the same as one of the others, then spend pages proving who might win based on union properties of quasi-components of compact sets. Riveting.

**Key Results:**  
Turns out, winning strategies exist under certain conditions, and these new games link back to classical ones. Spoiler: it’s mostly about structural properties in spaces that no one outside of topology will care about.

**Why It Matters:**  
If you’re into abstract topology and secretly love game theory, this might nudge your brain cells. For the rest of us mortal gamers? It’s a polite reminder that some “games” don’t involve any fun, just math that makes your head hurt.
